unnormalised: ## That Cart Abandonment Feeling: When "Add to Cart" Becomes "Add to My Stress"
normalised: That Cart Abandonment Feeling: When "Add to Cart" Becomes "Add to My Stress"

unnormalised: We've all been there, haven't we? Strolling through an online shop, picturing ourselves rocking that new kurta from Fabindia for Diwali, or finally getting that fancy pressure cooker Amma's been nagging us about. We gleefully click "Add to Cart," feeling that little rush of online retail therapy.
normalised: We've all been there, haven't we? Strolling through an online shop, picturing ourselves rocking that new kurta from Fabindia for Diwali, or finally getting that fancy pressure cooker Amma's been nagging us about. We gleefully click "Add to Cart," feeling that little rush of online retail therapy.

unnormalised: But then... reality hits harder than a Mumbai local train at rush hour. You see the final price, factoring in shipping to your remote village in Kerala, and suddenly that kurta isn't looking so essential. Maybe that pressure cooker can wait till next month.
normalised: But then... reality hits harder than a Mumbai local train at rush hour. You see the final price, factoring in shipping to your remote village in Kerala, and suddenly that kurta isn't looking so essential. Maybe that pressure cooker can wait till next month.

unnormalised: Suddenly, you're struck with that cart abandonment feeling. You close the tab, leaving those poor, lonely items to languish in your digital shopping basket. It's like ghosting your online retailer, but with potential financial repercussions (for them, not you… at least not immediately!).
normalised: Suddenly, you're struck with that cart abandonment feeling. You close the tab, leaving those poor, lonely items to languish in your digital shopping basket. It's like ghosting your online retailer, but with potential financial repercussions (for them, not you… at least not immediately!).

unnormalised: Retailers are practically tearing their hair out, wondering why customers like Ramesh added that antique Tanjore painting, saw the Rs. 10,000 shipping fee, and noped out faster than you can say "Biryani's ready!"
normalised: Retailers are practically tearing their hair out, wondering why customers like Ramesh added that antique Tanjore painting, saw the rupee ten thousand shipping fee, and noped out faster than you can say "Biryani's ready!"

unnormalised: Think of it this way: you've invited Biryani over, plated it beautifully, even got the raita ready...and then your stomach suddenly decides it wants Maggi instead. You leave the Biryani, untouched, heartbroken. That's how your abandoned cart makes the poor e-commerce site feel.
normalised: Think of it this way: you've invited Biryani over, plated it beautifully, even got the raita ready...and then your stomach suddenly decides it wants Maggi instead. You leave the Biryani, untouched, heartbroken. That's how your abandoned cart makes the poor e-commerce site feel.

unnormalised: So, what's the solution? Free shipping over Rs. 500, maybe? A gentle reminder email featuring a cute picture of a ganesh idol (everyone loves Ganesh, right?). Perhaps even a discount code shouting “Onam Special!”?
normalised: So, what's the solution? Free shipping over rupee five hundred, maybe? A gentle reminder email featuring a cute picture of a ganesh idol (everyone loves Ganesh, right?). Perhaps even a discount code shouting “Onam Special!”?

unnormalised: Whatever it is, retailers are desperately trying to win back your abandoned cart's affection. So next time you feel that "Add to Cart" turning into "Add to My Stress," remember the lonely Biryani, and maybe, just maybe, give that forgotten item a second chance. You might just find that kurta is *exactly* what your Diwali needs. And Amma will definitely thank you for the pressure cooker (even if the shipping fee was a bit of a sting).
